awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE Incubator: Network for the Integration of Natural History Collections in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experiences
awd_abstract_narration:
Undergraduate research increases student engagement, retention, and long-term success and is essential for building a scientifically literate and engaged workforce. The Ecology and Evolutionary Biology Course-based Research Experience (EEB-CURE) Network seeks to support the development of new course based undergraduate research experiences by leveraging the rapidly increasing availability of digitized natural history collections data. Embedding research experiences in biology and environmental science coursework is especially important for low income, first generation, and minority undergraduate students unable to dedicate time to research outside their normal course load due to personal and financial barriers. 

The EEB-CURE Network will create a community of undergraduate educators, natural history curators, education experts, and data experts who will explore how ecology and evolutionary biology classes can mine the hundreds of millions of data records being curated and served on web-based data portals such as iDigBio.org.   The first stage of this project will identify the challenges associated with developing course-based research experiences using natural history specimen data and determine what resources and training opportunities are critical for development of these courses.  Two surveys will be designed and distributed, one to assess the interest of biology educators in teaching CUREs using natural history collection data and the other to assess the interest of natural history collections professionals in collaborating with educators.  The surveys will also investigate the training and resource needs of both groups.  The project will recruit a diverse group of steering committee and network members who are passionate about the intersection of ecology, evolution, and natural history collections and who will actively promote the development of an upper-level biology CURE.  Faculty members who teach high proportions of underrepresented minorities and first-generation college students will be especially encouraged to participate in the network.  The culmination of the project will be a network meeting to review the results of the surveys and develop plans for training workshops, teaching materials, and collaboration opportunities to move the goals of the network forward.  

This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange/finalreport/).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Biological Collections in Ecology and Evolution Network (BCEENET) was created to expand access to undergraduate research opportunities in ecology and evolutionary biology. A network of undergraduate educators, natural history collections professionals, data experts, and education researchers was formed to support the development and dissemination of Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs). BCEENET CUREs use open access data from natural history collections that has been digitized and is freely available online to all students, regardless of institutional resources or location.

BCEENET hosted a 1-day virtual meeting in 2020 with 25 participants focused on network recruitment and developing a plan for future network activities and growth. Sessions introduced participants to natural history collections CUREs through presentations by invited speakers. Participants were then engaged in a CURE design activity focused on identifying the most effective ways to support the development of collections CUREs. Additionally, the network developed and implemented a survey to gauge interest in CUREs using digitized natural history collections and perceptions of the greatest challenges and needs for developing and implementing these CUREs. The results of the survey were used in combination with the outcomes of the virtual meeting to develop a framework for future network activities. This resulted in two funded NSF proposals for creating new CUREs using digitized collections data and supporting dissemination and implementation of the CUREs in the future. 

Additionally, the network hosted a 2-day virtual meeting in 2021 with 138 registered attendees. This meeting focused on equity and inclusion in access to undergraduate research experiences, dissemination of BCEENET CURE educational resources, and educator skills training. Sessions included a CURE beginner workshop, sessions on implementing BCEENET CUREs across diverse institutions and across different course formats, and brainstorming solutions to technology hurdles. The meeting also included sessions on inclusive CURE teaching strategies, diversity and inclusion in collections, and using open-access resources (e.g. QGIS, R, online environmental data).  Both virtual meetings were designed to support interactions between participants, building ties between and within the digitized natural history collections community and undergraduate education community.

Since the formation of BCEENET in 2019, the network has grown from 11 to 161 participants, with 247 individuals on the mailing list. These participants are from diverse institutions including many minority serving institutions, community colleges, and primarily undergraduate institutions. Network information and educational materials can be found on the BCEENET website (https://bceenetwork.org/) and on the QUBES BCEENET resources website (https://qubeshub.org/community/groups/bceenet). BCEENET network activities have led to the creation of four new CUREs using digitized natural history collections, that have provided over 1200 undergraduate students with research experiences. These inquiry-driven, active learning experiences provide students with opportunities to better understand the process of science. Additionally, these CUREs have been implemented at multiple minority serving institutions and community colleges, supporting equity in access to undergraduate research experiences. Through supporting CUREs using open-access, digitized natural history collections data, the network supports the development of a diverse 21st century STEM workforce.
